history.content:
It seems like you already saw the requirements to transfer, and meeting those definitely isn't enough to guarantee a successful transfer (Source: applied last semester and got rejected, applying again this semester).

There's a series of 6 documents you have to submit for the application, and there is one application cycle per semester. They take about one to two months to decide, sometimes a bit more. It's definitely very difficult to get in since the CoE is so impacted.

Bottom line, if you just want to go into software, just stick with L&S CS. It's a great program and doesn't hurt your chances in the industry. On the other hand if you really really want to be a hardware engineer and you like EE and Physics (like me!) then you should definitely give it a shot.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Why don't you take a look at the EECS minor? Anybody can declare the EECS minor (regardless of whether they are in CoE or not). That way, you can take some of the EE courses that you want without having to go through the extremely arduous process of getting into CoE? Just my two cents....

It seems like you already saw the requirements to transfer, and meeting those definitely isn't enough to guarantee a successful transfer (Source: applied last semester and got rejected, applying again this semester).

There's a series of 6 documents you have to submit for the application, and there is one application cycle per semester. They take about one to two months to decide, sometimes a bit more. It's definitely very difficult to get in since the CoE is so impacted.

Bottom line, if you just want to go into software, just stick with L&S CS. It's a great program and doesn't hurt your chances in the industry. On the other hand if you really really want to be a hardware engineer and you like EE and Physics (like me!) then you should definitely give it a shot.

children.subject: You could consider a LSCS Major. EE classes are rather easy to get into (compared to CS classes) and LSCS will give a good background in CS. Both LSCS and EECS can easily take EE classes. Keep in mind though that LSCS takes EE 16a usually in Spring and EECS takes 16a in Fall so you should plan your schedule accordingly.

history.content: I took a look at what my EECS friends were doing in their EE classes, and it seems really cool, and I thought that it might be worth it to transfer to the EECS major. I took a look at the requirements to transfer, and was wondering whether meeting the requirements suffices for transferring (or whether the process is more complicated than that). I would appreciate it if anyone has any insight or can share their experience with the transfer process. Thanks in advance!
history.subject: Transferring to EECS from L&S
